awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cross-Linguistic Investigations of Syntactic Creativity Errors in Children's Wh-questions
awd_abstract_narration:
Children show remarkable aptitude for learning language and have mastered much of the grammar of their language by age four. This remarkable skill has led to the hypothesis that children come to this task with an innate ability to learn certain types of grammatical patterns, namely those manifested in the languages of the world. Through exposure, they learn which patterns are relevant to their language. For example, children learning English initially produce a type of complex questions not grammatical in English, but resembling grammatical German questions. Over time, they learn this pattern is not English and no longer use it. An alternative explanation for these errors is that limited general cognitive capacities, specifically memory, attention, and sentence planning result in productions which only superficially resemble German questions. The goal of the project is to tease apart these possible explanations through controlled experimentation comparing elicited questions and answers by English speaking children and by German speaking children. The two hypotheses predict different error types. If the errors are the result of an innate predisposition, German speaking children should produce some questions resembling English. If the errors are the result of limited cognitive abilities, children learning each language should produce questions which are not consistent with such a predisposition. This research holds the potential to be used as a clinical diagnostic for investigating children's linguistic and cognitive development. 

The research comprises novel experiments designed to test production and comprehension of multiclausal questions. Children between the ages of four and six will be given tests designed to assess their attention, working memory, and sentence planning abilities. By comparing performance of English and German speaking children, this project will further illuminate the role of input in language learning and provide a baseline for comparison for English-speaking children. Novel contributions include furthering the use and integration of psycholinguistic methodologies into linguistic work as well as investigating German children's as yet unstudied acquisition of this complex syntactic phenomenon.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project investigated how children learn to ask and answer questions with complex syntactic structures like "Who do you think we should ask?" and "How did Jane tell Jeremy what she saw?". English-speaking children make lots of mistakes when asking and answering these questions, but that is not surprising. Being able to ask and answer this type of question requires that you not only understand the complex syntax, but that you are able to designate the appropriate processing resources to the task. Our experiments involved having kindergarten-aged children play games that got them to either ask or answer these types of questions. We also measured their working memory as an indicator of their processing resources.

Furthermore, we conducted this experiment with both English and German-speaking children. This involved going to Germany and training research assistants at the University of Konstanz to translate and run the experiment. This was to be sure that there was not something specific to English that made these questions difficult and caused the errors children were making. 

Finally, we conducted surveys of adult native speakers of English, Hindi, Hungarian, and German in order to determine when and how speakers used varying forms of these questions. This was to help us understand the scenarios which elicited these types of questions and to understand what it takes to be a fully native speaker of these languages. 

We learned several important things in the process of doing this study. First, we found that children's performance on our langauge tasks were srongly linked to their performance on the working memory task. This suggests that it is children's immature processing mechanisms that are causing them to make mistakes. Furthermore, we found very similar errors as well as this same correlation between working memory and errors in German-speaking children. This suggests that the errors are not the result of an English-specific problem, but rather something that English and German speaking children share: their immature processing mechanisms. Finally, the surveys we conducted with adult speakers across languages have taught us that speakers of different languages use different forms of questions in different scenarios. This not only adds to our understanding of the variation in languages, it helps us to understand what becoming fluent in each of these langauges means for the children.

Our work has resulted in important professional development for the doctoral student who lead the work as well as for two German research assistants and two English speaking research assistants. It has also resulted in the development of professional collaboration between researchers at our institution and the University of Konstanz. 

Our findings hold significance not only for linguists, but for developmental psychologists. We also hope that our findings will be informative to those who teach or work with kindergarten-aged children.

Modified by: Carolyn J Lutken
